Is there a way to define a field an "take models of field theory" in a category via functors like we do with Lawvere theories?

Ah, yes, good advice. Upon checking, it was immediately clear that I was wrong! Here's something that I /did/ check:

Consider the (countably infinite) meadow MMM of finite-support functions from N\mathbb{N}N to Z/2Z\mathbb{Z}/2\mathbb{Z}Z/2Z. This is a commutative ring, and every element is idempotent and hence its own generalized inverse. But it cannot be a product of fields: for, each factor FFF in such a product would contain some nonzero element of the meadow MMM and thus would contain some sub-ring isomorphic to Z/2Z\mathbb{Z}/2\mathbb{Z}Z/2Z; consequently, FFF would have characteristic 222. However, since the meadow MMM has no element that obeys x4=xx^4=xx4=x without also obeying x2=xx^2=xx2=x, each factor FFF must be the minimal characteristic 222 field, namely Z/2Z\mathbb{Z}/2\mathbb{Z}Z/2Z. So MMM would be a product of Z/2Z\mathbb{Z}/2\mathbb{Z}Z/2Z s. But, whether this product is finitary or infinitary, it cannot have the same cardinality as MMM, since 2finite<countable<2countable2^{\text{finite}} < \text{{countable}} < 2^{\text{countable}}2finite<countable<2countable.

Here's something that might be useful:
Consider the monoidal category of pointed sets with the smash product. A monoid internal to this category is just an ordinary monoid equipped with a 000 (a two-sided absorbing element).
The Hopf-algebras internal to this category are groups with a 000 adjoined to them; which are precisely the multiplicative structures we want fields to have.
So you could define fields by demanding a Hopf-algebra structure on their underlying pointed sets.

That's quite nice, actually. You could think of defining a “relative theory” to be a morphism of PROPs P→QP \to QP→Q, and a “relative model” to be a commutative square of monoidal functors from P→QP \to QP→Q to a functor F:C→DF: \mathcal{C} \to \mathcal{D}F:C→D.

I find this quote from the introduction, "However, many approaches contain an explicit definition of F1\mathbb{F}_1F1​, and in most cases, the field with one element is not a field and has two elements. Namely, the common answer of many theories is that F1\mathbb{F}_1F1​ is the multiplicative monoid {0,1}\{0,1\}{0,1}, lacking any additive structure," rather strange. Having seen Connes talk on this subject, he talks about F1\mathbb{F}_1F1​ as a semifield (or at least refers to the semifield B\mathbb{B}B whose multiplicative structure is that mentioned above, with max⁡\maxmax as addition), so there is an additive structure, there's just no subtraction.

Right, many people actually do consider that additive structure at times. I think a good example of what he's referring to can be found in this paper: https://arxiv.org/pdf/1308.0042.pdf Equations of tropical varieties by Giansiracusa and Giansiracusa.

Rather than defining an object F1\mathbb F_1F1​, one starts by defining the category of modules, F1\mathbb F_1F1​-Mod, to be the category of pointed sets. The basepoint of an F1\mathbb F_1F1​-module M is denoted 0M and is called the zero element of M. This category has a closed symmetric monoidal tensor product ⊗ given by the smash product of pointed sets (take the cartesian product and then collapse the subset M × {0N} ∪ {0M} ×N to the basepoint). The two-point set {0,1} is a unit for this tensor product. An F1\mathbb F_1F1​-algebra is an F1\mathbb F_1F1​-module A equipped with a commutative and unital product map A⊗A→ A (i.e., it is a commutative monoid in F1\mathbb F_1F1​-Mod). Concretely, an F1\mathbb F_1F1​-algebra is a commutative and unital monoid with a (necessarily unique) element 0A such that 0A · x = 0A for all x; thus F1\mathbb F_1F1​-algebras, as defined here, are sometimes called monoids-with-zero. The two-point set {0,1} admits a multiplication making it an F1\mathbb F_1F1​-algebra, and it is clearly an initial object, so we can denote it by F1\mathbb F_1F1​ and speak of F1\mathbb F_1F1​-algebras without ambiguity.
